author: trent_vanepps
content: can you expand on what you mean here?

author: vorot93
content: if you just sync state without validating history, then you can remove a lot of code necessary for executing those old blocks

author: vorot93
content: if all implementations do it, then we have officially dropped past history, with the earliest available block being regenesis date

author: pipermerriam
content: I like this... Need to think on it a bit but my intuition says that if clients had a flag for "--sync-till-height" then you could still execute a full sync by working your way through old versions of the client, using whatever old version last supported that range of blocks.

author: pipermerriam
content: In theory that allows client simplification without actually fully removing the ability to do a full sync of you really really care...

author: pipermerriam
content: This would effect some of the json-rpc apis that allow execution against old blocks (in archive mode)

author: sky.cactus
content: I think this only works if clients at least keep around their legacy networking code.  Geth has been trying hard to do the opposite and drop it.

author: pipermerriam
content: right, this might need to exist in some sort of "offline" mode where you feed it the blocks.

author: sky.cactus
content: I would rather see block history made available via torrent or something (not part of core protocol, but generally supported/agreed on).  Then each client would let you import from the pre-downloaded history.

author: sky.cactus
content: Each client would need a final version that supports the torrent downloaded format of history.

author: pipermerriam
content: If clients choose to freeze history in some manner, we'll very likely make it available in a "torrent-like" fashion via portal

author: sky.cactus
content: Though, I have never really understood why people feel the need to validate all history personally.

author: pipermerriam
content: agreed, but it's one of those things that I still think you should be able to do if you want to

author: sky.cactus
content: What ultimately matters is whether or not you are on the same chain as the people you want to interact with.

author: sky.cactus
content: And that can be fetched with just a single blockhash and a data provider.

author: gcolvin
content: If you can create a node with all of the history, fully validated, you can do lots of useful things more quickly.  Like like scanning or querying all of the transactions.  Or testing code changes by making sure you can still run previous contracts. (I just dropped in here, so ignore me if this is irrelevant.)

author: pipermerriam
content: We're pretty far off-topic, lets move this to <#731173407064064011> if there any more discussion people want to have about this idea
